page.title: 16SOUTH DOWNS EAST OF N. STOKE
page.content: Two kilometres east of North Stoke, facing south, lies a stretch of land apparently wholly arable. A wide horse-shoe of tree tops visible in the distance, is in fact the tip of a tree clad hanger dropping abruptly from sight and concealing at its foot a swampy area of marsh and sedge. This marsh is edged on its western side by the old Arun meander with its river bed dense with willows and water- loving undergrowth, curving away to rejoin the Arun at South Stoke. As the hanger runs south its height decreases giving way to a strip of deciduous woodland cutting across the farmland. Within one kilometre square the dry chalk South Downs with arable crops give way by this dramatic drop in height to the uncultivated marsh below the hanger and, within the meander, grassland reclaimed by drainage dykes.
